reviews.advice:
Your "Culture of We" is moot with how you treat your consultants and analysts. Consultants are left holding the bag for everyone else even though we actually do the work contained within the RFPs and SoWs.

If something is a bonus, don't sic your HR dogs on me when I choose not to participate. Make it mandatory if you want it to be mandatory. Meaning, if I don't have a project to give you, then you should have a conversation with the sales team as to why they can't sell any projects, not come down on consultants because that's not our job. If your headhunter recruiters and TAs can't find anyone to work, that's their problem, not ours. Maybe they should spend less time making cute posts on LinkedIn and actually do something productive. I am working a project for you. The bonuses would be nice, and I would be happy to receive a referral bonus or the project generation bonus, but I can't just make things up out of thin air, and I am uncomfortable doing so because, and I know this is a foreign concept to most management and HR at this company, I have a moral compass and don't like to lie or cheat my way to the top. I work hard. Dang hard. And I'm smart, capable, and a quick learner. No matter how I feel or how you have treated me, you'll never take any of that away from me. That is my main job. Sales and recruitment doesn't get engaged when consultants need help on their projects, so why do sales and recruitment get catered to, and consultants are forced to do the catering? Also, why do consultants get the boot when recruitment and sales can't generate clients, employees, and projects?

I can confidently say, after being furloughed and officially severed, I don't think anyone at this company ever gave a dang (I wish Glassdoor would let me use my four-letter words. Just assume them) about me or anyone else in my situation. No one is even helping me find new work after treating the others and me so poorly. They know how bad the job market is right now, and it's frightening that they still sleep soundly at night after how they've treated some of us.

However, all of this said, this is just the culture in this god-awful country. I doubt you'll change anything, and I'm sure your HR pawn is going to come reply to this talking about all of those "accolades" given to you by companies run by other rich people and say a bunch of buzzwords to try and soften the blow. Yawn. Real people can see what working for you is like. I'm more mad at myself for trusting any of you to do the right thing. Thought I finally found a company that treats its workers with respect and would fight the good fight. Never again. Congrats Logic, I will never trust another company ever again in my life. Companies and corporations want to complain that no one is loyal anymore. Well, this kind of culture and business ethic is the cause. You know the scene in Billy Madison where they're doing the Jeopardy-esque competition, and Billy chooses Business Ethics for his opponent, and his opponent has a total meltdown because his opponent (the antagonist trying to take over Madison Hotels) has no moral compass to even have a grasp of what ethical behavior is within the context of running a business, and he's essentially just a greed-monger? That's a metaphor for the leadership, HR, and management at Logic.

I find it very strange how many new hires I've seen with Logic recently on LinkedIn when you've just furloughed/severed so many good people. "We always work hard to find projects for our consultants, but it can be difficult sometimes." as other replies have said. Riiiiight. Lots of hiring going on. The math ain't mathing! :) Keep towing that line, though, HR person.

Also, I noticed the most recent 4-star review was from a former employee that started at least 5 years ago and has subsequently moved on. Coincidentally, that review was submitted on August 7th, after your most recent mass layoff. A random ex employee coming to give a 3+ star review during a time of poor reviews isn't a good look when you're good at connecting dots, Logic. ;) Either you're creating fake reviews, or you're reaching out to old employees and begging them to offset the negative reviews because of your greedy, self-absorbed leadership/HR/management. Nice. Hey, maybe it's a coincidence. (Doubt it.)

"If you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life thinking it's stupid." Companies need to stop putting all of the load of training and upskilling on their employees and candidates. Most anyone can do anything with the right amount of guidance, training, and mentorship. Your company offers none. Your CDLs basically just say "Here's this vague area you could upskill in" and that's only if you're lucky with a CDL with some semblance of leadership and mentorship. That's not guidance. That's not training. That's acting like you're guiding people, and getting your "dopamine candy" and tricking your brain into believing you're actually doing something when you aren't, oh and fluffing your resume with a bogus title that you didn't actually do anything to earn.
reviews.cons:
Where to begin:

-As much as they claim in the replies, they don't value loyalty. They don't care how hard you work for them. You are on the chopping block at all times, and they'll make excuse after excuse about how "hard" it is to find projects for people. Interesting that a consulting firm's main barrier is... *checks notes* consulting projects. Maybe your sales team and TAs are just... bad at their jobs? If most of your replies say "It's difficult to find projects for people", then shouldn't you realize that the way your sales team goes about finding and securing projects is wrong? But that's another issue thrown onto the backs of the consultants. Essentially, if you want a project to work on, you have to generate it yourself while sales does... something? If I wanted to generate my own projects, I would be an independent consultant.

-Don't let the day 1 smiles and camaraderie fool you. Lots of crossed fingers behind backs. There will come a time where you're thrown to the wolves, no matter how hard you worked for them.

-Leadership is two-faced, and mid-management/HR tows the line, as evidenced by the other reviews gaslighting employees basically saying the "you aren't good enough, and your job is to do better to serve your corporate masters" schtick. Ironically, I would if they would just let me know what to train for them. They have no idea what they want you to do, so they can literally offer no guidance in how you can upskill, even if it's FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COMPANY.

-If you're furloughed or severed, you're hit with the classic corporate gaslight of "think of the business". I'll get right on that. I'm glad you're considering I don't know where my next mortgage payment is going to come from just because the execs want a bigger EoY bonus. My audaciousness in not "thinking of the business" is noted.

-Speaking of execs, no matter how much they want to sing the praises of the CFO, she's clearly read too many Ayn Rand books, leading to cutthroat policies when things get a little difficult. "Screw you, I got mine" is the actual culture of this company, regardless of all of their virtue signaling and empty words.

-Regardless of DEI/Volunteer policies, they WILL sever/furlough you as soon as it's inconvenient for them to keep you on payroll, no matter if you're a straight, white man or a BIPOC woman or anything in between. I worked with all types. And all types got furloughed/laid off. It's part of business, it's not necessary, but corporations act like it is. Their first and only concern is their bottom line. It's not even a publicly traded company, so they have no SEC laws holding them down with "bUt ThE sHaReHoLdErS" routines. The leadership and management could take a pay cut or a bonus reduction, any corporation could, but they'll never choose that path even though they're essentially running a dying business. "Screw you, I got mine" again. They basically make you feel secure in your job, everyone in your professional circle is totally unaware and thinks you're going to be benched, and then the day of a meeting titled "Bench Sync" they tell you you have 8 hours to decide whether you want to choose furlough or severance. The only difference is with severance, you get one extra paycheck on top of your eventual PTO payout (if you have any accrued), and with furlough, you don't get that paycheck but you keep your healthcare benefits for up to 90 days while they "try to find a project for you" and you're "top priority" for any projects that come about. So basically, you're given the choice of an extra paycheck to pay your bills for a slightly longer amount of time or rolling the dice and hoping that they find you a project. A DEI/Volunteer policy that is rendered null due to how quickly these people will throw you to the wolves when their exec bonuses are threatened.  They don't care about human beings. Therefore, they can't care about a subset of marginalized human beings. If you're given the option, just sever. They're not going to find you a project, and it's just better to hurt their wallet and hopefully try to teach them the way they're treating people is wrong.

-They give you no warning. I knew my project was coming to an end, and I made the obviously terrible choice of trusting them to put me on the bench. I should have started to look for another job, but I trusted their golden smiles. Everyone around me was totally shocked to learn I was being furloughed/severed. However, they could have given me professional courtesy and said "Hey, we don't have any spots on the bench. If we can't find you a project when this one ends, you'll probably be furloughed." And, to be clear, I wasn't the only person furloughed in this group. This is clearly a greed move. I got nothing but starry-eyed reviews from anyone involved in my circle - coworkers, CDL, and managers. It wasn't a performance-based layoff. When I pressed on this issue, their response was "Well we don't want to lose our good people." Got it. So, your idea of "not losing your best people" is basically waiting until the last second to let someone know their mortgage is insecure. Honestly, this review wouldn't be half as scathing as it is if they had just given me a fair warning. But their chosen option is to spring a furlough on you at the flip of a switch. Disgusting. Again, a self-absorbed way to handle the situation. Profits over people. Yes, HR person replying to this, I know, I know - "While we are continually looking to generate profits..." Yawn. I can't be bothered to care. Ya know. Got that whole "mortgage" thing I'm worried about. Not that that moves any of you.

-They celebrate tenured employees constantly at quarterly all-hands meetings. The problem with this is, unless you're part of the good ol' boys and girls club that came into the company from the UK/Australia with the CEO, it's pretty impossible to achieve any sort of tenure due to how easily they'll just furlough/sever people. And, at a certain point, your idea of celebrating tenure and loyalty becomes nothing more than patting yourselves on the back for furloughing people. They don't care how hard you work for them, they don't care how much effort you give, they will treat you like every other company in the US. "Profits over people. Screw the workers. Make sure leadership stays rich." They claim they invest every dollar back into the company, but if that were true, they wouldn't be furloughing and severing people at a moment's notice. Leadership would take the hit, and create more bench space with money redirected from exec salaries and bonuses. They don't. You're worthless to them. A worm on a sidewalk.

-As a consultant, you aren't just a consultant. You also have to do sales and recruitment as well. These roles are purported to be bonus ventures for consultants, but if you don't participate, you get to have a 1on1 with a snarky HR person and explain why you didn't participate and give out your friends' and family's personal information out for free. And "I don't know anyone who has the power or money to pay for a consulting project" isn't an acceptable answer. I had even referred a couple of friends already, but that didn't count. They wanted new names for their lists exactly when they demanded them. Do you all think we have gigantic social circles? Look up Dunbar's Number on Wikipedia and get back to me. I'm sure they'll turn around and gaslight me here and say, "Well, you'd be on a project if you had found one for yourself." Then what do you pay the sales people for? If I'm expected to generate my own projects, then what's the point of even having a sales department?

-They're extremely inconsiderate. You are just a pawn in their money game. An example of this is them pushing you to use up all of your PTO. At first glance, this sounds great. It sounds like the company cares about your well-being. What it really is, though, is insidiously pushing you to take vacations when you aren't prepared/don't want to so they don't have to pay out liquid cash when they inevitably find a reason to furlough/sever you.

-Most revenue comes from Microsoft projects for staff aug. Basically, if you have an 18-6 badge from Microsoft, you're at extreme risk of losing your job if they don't find you another project when your 18 months is up. And they're putting all of their eggs in one basket. So, when, I don't know, hypothetically, if they tick off your Microsoft client, they're essentially sowing seeds of discontent within Microsoft. I know of a client that has sworn off entertaining any RFPs from Logic due to terrible management of a project coming from at least three steps above me. That cookie is going to crumble, no matter how many rugby matches the CEO wants to go play with Microsoft employees. Every disgruntled Microsoft client is a sown seed of discord that will bring that eventuality to pass. It's like they have no conception of how other people operate and function. If I'm someone's friend or trusted coworker, and they tell me "Hey, I once worked with this firm and it was awful. I wouldn't advise" there's no amount of cute sales pitches from Halo Effecters that is going to make me take them up on their offer. Plenty of consulting firms around to choose from. One bad review is a death knell, and an easy way to cross someone off a list. I know I've told everyone I know that I'd never work for them again, and I'd advise them not to work for Logic either. If I did, I'd be off-project ASAP after continuing looking for other forms of employment while on-project. If they want to treat me like a disposable peon, then I'll treat them like a paycheck. Nothing more. Nothing less. Logic doesn't deserve me or the people they've screwed over. They claim they're trying to break into other markets, but I wouldn't trust anything they say as far as I can throw a 100 pound rock at this point.

-The career development is a ruse. They basically claim they help you develop your career, but it's all on paper. They give you no direction or guidance. They don't tell you what to learn or how you can better contribute, it's up to you to decide to go learn something, and if it's a skill they don't need for any potential projects in the pipeline you basically just wasted your time. If you're furloughed, there's no support to help you get back on your feet somewhere else. Not even a casual networking offer. They essentially want you to work for them or not at all even if you're not employed by them. And, let's just say they get REAL mad if your project is coming to an end and a consultant decides to jump ship instead of trusting them to do the right thing. EVERYTHING is a projection coming from the top, HR, and mid-management.

-All furloughs and bad things happening are just "flukes" and "bumps in the road" every time the question is asked in quarterly all-hands meetings. The weird part is it's becoming a pattern that they won't acknowledge. And, rest assured, they NEVER "foresee any further furloughs and layoffs coming. We really think the market is taking a turn for the better." It's always just a lie to keep you passive and lull you to sleep. If I was a betting person, I'd bet they're always looking for ways to furlough/sever people with how many times and people I've seen it happen to in the short time I was there. There's definitely a loose pattern that has been established.

- I told my CDL that I was willing to learn anything and work any project. They said that's a good thing because some people are picky about their projects. I'm not. I'm really a great employee with a penchant for learning anything new that the company wants me to, but there's no direction. They have no pipelines to advise employees to tell them what to do to help better contribute. I just want a living wage and a decent work/life balance, and that's too much for Logic to handle.

-They engage their non-compete clauses. I know that for a fact. Won't go further because I'm sure they'll come after me if I do.

-Digital Transformation consultants! - If your project is coming to an end, they will put ONE of you on a massive project, make you take the heat from the client, and essentially turn you into a meat shield so mid and upper management doesn't have to. I felt awful for the DT consultant on my project. They worked that poor person to the bone...

employerResponses.response:
Thank you for taking the time to provide a review of your experience at Logic20/20 and your thoughts around the furlough process. It’s clear from your experience that we need to do a better job of how we communicate furloughs, how the bench is managed, and how consulting leadership and sales work together on a weekly basis to find projects our team, including those on project, on bench, or on furlough.

Outside of your feedback on the furlough process, leadership, and company culture, we do want to address a few points in your statement.
•	Our non-complete clause does not prohibit Logic20/20 employees or former employees from working for competitors or at companies where we do business. 
•	Logic20/20 closely manages our badge lifecycles with companies that we do business with and works to place people into new accounts during “badge breaks.” It’s a critical function of our business to manage and maintain. 

If you have further questions about the concerns that you raised in your review, please reach out to hr@logic2020.com – we’d be happy to set up time to talk.

reviews.pros:
-Decent benefits with 401k (2% match), healthcare premiums are covered, PTO, work/life balance (for the most part). According to other reviews, wages are lower than market value. When I pressed this, I was met with an incredulous reply. I was pretty ok where I was at, but workers need to band together and get what they're owed from the rich. So, if it's low, I'll always side with my fellows in the working class as I don't tow the line or act as a lap dog like HR and mid-management does. It's low.

- Non-management employees are a delight to work with that don't just tow the line and throw you under the bus when they can get ahead by doing so. Mid-management, HR, and leadership cannot be spoken for here.

-Great place to get your foot in the door to better options. This is not a company you can spend a lot of time at as they will furlough/sever you at a moment's notice even when you bust your tail for them. (This is @ consultants only. Plenty of HR and mid-management that can "water cooler talk" and tow the line (aka bootlick) their way into staying for multiple years. Nothing you can do as a consultant other than do your job well and hope you get to stay.
reviews.summary: You are expendable, and the "culture" is a ruse. Two-faced. Expect to be laid off at a moment's notice.

reviews.advice: Foster a true consultant culture, not the superficial brainwashing and make-believe. Treat people with respect. Recognize your senior contributors, instead of alienating them. Give employees a true sense of ownership in the business success instead of communist style central planning squashing any individual drive toward excellence.
reviews.cons: Too many chiefs, too few warriors: Manager versus IC ratio = 40/60. Micro-management by incompetentn, non-caring managers who are driven by financial greed, not best interest of client. Frequently put consultants in cross fire for doing the right thing for client versus being blindly obedient toward ignorant management. Many pre-sales opportunities (referrals) fell through for lack of follow-through. Consultants get punished for doing the right thing for client. Management is more busy with their own self-importance. Employees are held accountable to retro-actively changing objectives at review time. Employees are not rewarded for doing great client work. Projects are grossly mis-managed, if managed at all. Even though called "consultants", work is actually hourly body-shop work, hourly rate is all that seems to matter.
reviews.pros: The majority of the individual contributors (field consultants) are a great bunch to work with. Super intelligent, motivated, social, helpful.
reviews.summary: Management is incompetent, disrespectful, unethical and greedy

reviews.advice: Continue to shape the company with strategic direction and focus. As expansion occurs, don't lose sight of the small company feel.
reviews.cons: Some resources are lacking in terms of standardized training or learning opportunities but individual requests are always taken into consideration by upper management. Also, internal communications needs to be improved to keep up with all of the professional and social activities going on.
reviews.pros:
Logic20/20 provides employees at every level of the organization with the opportunity to learn and grow in a fast-paced and professional environment. The company prides itself on hiring intelligent and hardworking individuals and offers a variety of career paths in management, business consulting, and technical consulting.  

In addition to working on interesting projects and with great clients, employees also benefit from monthly social events and close partnerships with local and global non-profit organizations. Logic20/20 believes in a strong company culture and continually provides consultants with the opportunity to provide candid feedback.

The company is led by a focused and caring senior leadership team that put consultant and client interests ahead of their own. Hardworking and dedicated employees are rewarded with a competitive benefits package and bonus structure.
reviews.summary: Great people, fun culture, growing company

reviews.advice: Be more clear about what you're hiring for. If you need software developers, fine. But if you need consultants that are just salesmen, hire for that.
reviews.cons:
The office culture was very old school (in my experience). You must dress better, speak better and smell better than the clients. Even if your client is wearing death metal t-shirts to work, you must be dressed in business, which in the developer world makes you look like an outcast. Instead of being part of the 'team' I was the weird one.

It practically took an act of congress to take time off. In my experience it took multiple approvals internally and then from the client. 

The mandatory consultant training is one of the most painful experiences of my career, and I've done a few of them with other companies. It seems to be more focused on dressing appropriately and finding more business than anything.  

It does amaze me that this place is able to get developers in Seattle. If you're just a salesman then you'll be in the right place. If you want to write awesome software and be treated like a grown up, find another place.
reviews.pros:
They have their foot in the door at some good companies which can lead to some good experiences if you put in the time.

Compensation was fine for the market.
reviews.summary: Worst consulting company I've ever worked for if you want to write awesome software

reviews.advice:
-Consider the questionable ethics of rich white guys exploiting minority-owned business status.
-Compare your attrition rate to other consulting companies and ask yourself what you're doing wrong, or just own up to being a staffing agency.
-Be a better place to work by offering enough PTO that a person can afford to, in the same year, go on vacation AND be able to not work if seriously ill.
reviews.cons:
-Run by a bunch of privileged white guys who are somehow managing to exploit minority-owned business incentives. Only one female in senior leadership. All senior leadership is white. Very much a good old boys club. A particularly obnoxious leader actually referred to my adult female colleague as "that girl," because despite her years of tenure, he couldn't recall her name.
-Unpleasant and uncomfortable physical work environments both at Logic and at Microsoft.
-Unreal attrition: 100-person company and at least 10 people left in my first month.
-You are only as good as your billable hours.
-Professional development opportunities are meaningless except to those with very new careers.
reviews.pros:
This might be a good place to build your resume if you're inexperienced, and you end up on a good project (or projects), and you're willing to be deal with crappy benefits and PTO for a year or two.

Talented coworkers and dedicated administrative staff.
reviews.summary: Mostly a low-rent Microsoft staffing firm

reviews.advice: Hone in on specialty niches--either industry concentration or very specific capabilities that differentiate us from our competitors.
reviews.cons:
Turnover feels high, and it's always hard to see friends move onto other companies.  The good news is that people leave for varying reasons, but it's typically positive--going to work for a client, using a skill set developed at Logic to make big $ at Amazon, travel the world.  

Also, the 401k matching program is indisputably awful.
reviews.pros: I've been with the firm for two years and experienced high-five worthy successes and a few disappointing lows on projects and internal activities.  What's unique at Logic is that the I have yet to feel like management is looking for opportunity to call me out on my mistakes.  Instead, the environment is intentionally set up to support you and help you grow.  If your client is flying off the handle, Logic will do its best to understand and empathize with the consultant as its first reaction.  Any "learning opportunities" would truly be just that and not punitive in nature.  If you're from a Big 4 or investment banking background, it's going to feel odd that management and your peers genuinely care about you and your well being.

reviews.advice: Where/When possible, build in 2-3 days of official onboarding time at Logic20/20 before new hires are set to begin with a client.
reviews.cons: After a lengthy recruiting and onboarding process, I suddenly had a very compressed schedule to begin work both at Logic20/20 and with my client..  I essentially had to learn two jobs at once, feeling like I was in over my head.  That being said, I was able to "tread water" after two weeks.
reviews.pros: I first connected with a Logic20/20 recruiter in Aug '15 and finally joined the company in Mar '16.  The onboarding timeline - from initial meeting, to successive interviews, to job placement - took longer than I would have hoped, but my counterparts at Logic20/20 were very open and honest throughout the process.  I always knew what to expect, had scheduled times to check-in with my recruiter, and was given ample opportunity to meet with prospective clients.  It was worth the wait and I am very happy with my new company and my first client.  I feel that I was set up for success and intend to deliver accordingly.

reviews.advice: Keep staying in tune with the market and keep improving benefits.
reviews.cons:
* This really isn't that much of a con but, you need to be able to speak with leadership and all is good.  Need to be a strong individual as opportunities won't just come to you.  You need to be proactive to get the types of contracts/experiences you want.
* 401k isn't much.
* Yearly review process could be improved by not having an intermediary.  Leadership needs to speak directly to the leads & PMs to understand each employee's review, instead of getting it collated and presented to them (that being said, the reviews are fair and lead to good things for the coming year).
reviews.pros:
* Leadership works hard to make sure it is a great work environment
* They truly do their best to make sure the client is always happy
* They learn.  They will admit to not doing as well as they wanted and are not afraid of trying new things to consistently keep a great working environment while growing and adapting to the market.
reviews.summary: Leadership strives to make a great working environment and grow at the same time

reviews.advice: Keep moving forward and sending the elevator back down...
reviews.cons: Career management program could use more communication.  They’re shoring up gaps in the onboarding programs.  Their systems, while being upgraded, lack the sophisticated integration needed for a company of this size and growth curve.  Some of this is due to growing so quickly and just not having enough time/staff to tackle as they would like.
reviews.pros: Doors are open to new ideas, thoughts and suggestions.  Culturally open-minded.  Employee focused - they care about the individual.  Expertise from all levels of the organization.  Dedicated, thoughtful, brave, bold and confident.  There's a high degree of courage from the leadership; to not only constantly review their positions on major subjects within, but also in their willingness to take intelligent chances, whether in new business, client engagements, or employee programs.  They also have enough belief in their own values and ethos as a culture, that they are willing to turn down business they're unable to provide a high degree of quality control to.  Technically, they're changing the game in certain areas.   They've also hired new talent and their growth outside of the greater Seattle area is accelerating.

reviews.cons:
Interview process can last several months to determine if you will be a good fit for the company and a fit for available/potential projects. They have plenty of articles as a fastest growing company or the best place to work for, but there is a high turnover. My time spent interviewing was not worth the outcome. 
Many moving parts, skills/practice mismatch. No visibility on project opportunities to apply - you are basically left with trusting management to find a fit for your "dream" project. Noone is perfect, right? - look into the risk of not having a project, or filling in for just an ad-hoc project. Overall, you might end up underutilizing your potential and skills, or lacking knowledge leverage. They do offer free courses for different certs but it's not the same as the real experience. 
Management invests heavily into marketing of its  "We" culture with lots of events and happy hours. It's all great but instead I'd rather have a better 401K match or unlimited free parking, especially with such a revenue growth rate!
reviews.pros: Company has a good footprint in Seattle, many happy hours and events, friendly people,  flexibility, opportunity to study for certifications, coffee and snacks.
reviews.summary: High turnover vs. Long interview process

reviews.cons: Salaries aren't quite as high as other similarly-sized consultancies, but in my opinion, I am compensated very fairly and the culture and career growth Logic offers is worth the tradeoff compared to what I could be making elsewhere. You will need to decide for yourself what matters most to you - for me, happiness > pay.
reviews.pros:
People and culture - you get out what you put in, but this company cares about its employees and their individual well-being, so protecting work-life balance is supported and encouraged. I got lots of mileage out of 1:1s and mentorships.

Career opportunities - Career management is employee-driven, as it should be, but in my experience Logic has been great about meeting me where I am and giving me opportunities to try new things aligned with my goals, often much sooner in my career than I would have gotten elsewhere. Approach it with patience and humility and you will be taken care of.
reviews.summary: Great place to accelerate your career

reviews.advice: Think broadly about planning company events and how remote workers can be included. Offer a competitive 401K because a 1% match is deplorable. Don't gaslight your employees or use the client as a scapegoat.
reviews.cons: Lack of benefit options, role expectations are typically unclear, lack of internal structure, remote employees are often an afterthought when planning company events, and lack of transparency.
reviews.pros: Fully remote, flexible work schedules depending on the project, set your own career growth and pace, competitive salary, great health insurance.

reviews.advice:
Hire more diverse individuals for management roles. 

Ensure employees are being paid a livable wage. Improve the lack of sustainable (long term) contracts as it will improve the quality of the companies work and their employees quality of life. 

Get more parking. 

Put together a training for management regarding how to be effective leaders instead of fear mongers.
reviews.cons:
Cliquey, unrealistic expectations, lack of parking in a busy area. There are inconsistent work opportunities (contracts tend to end early which is stated as allowed in the employee contracts). 

Lots of favoritism for the privileged employees (example invites to executives homes etc).

Huge lack of diversity here as well. Management = mainly wealthy white men or women. One manager was extremely passive aggressive and irritable. I was not given clear info or guidance on issues but then would get written up for said issues I was unaware of.  I was bullied by this manager (called names like “idiot” and given eye rolls etc) as were numerous other individuals during company meetings. When this was raised with HR no changes or training occurred.

Lack of understanding for common life occurrences/issues is big here unless you’re in management. Execs + mgmt are unaware and insensitive regarding normal life problems.

Health insurance is subpar at best.

Managers are chosen based off of discriminatory practices, not based off who is best fit for the role.

Overall, unless you’re a wealthy and/or privileged individual you will not succeed here. You will be pushed out.
reviews.pros:
I learned a lot during the years I was here as I was assigned a helpful, honest, mentor. My mentor was close with my manager so they gave me the complaints they got from my manager so I could adjust accordingly.

I also had many managers while there as they tend to change the managers on the contracts a lot due to them leaving for better opportunities but one was amazing. They have amazing company events as well. 

People are friendly in a very surface-level way but not generally rude.

reviews.cons: Some of the coworkers were just okay
reviews.pros: Getting some projects with big companies

reviews.cons: Narrow and limited career growth
reviews.pros: Open to feedback, welcoming team, supporting colleagues, friendly.

reviews.cons: Company isn't structured to be able to hold top talent or get through adversity
reviews.pros: Good place to start developing your basic skillset for consulting

reviews.cons: Very small and didn't do the best job at supporting new employee.
reviews.pros: Life balance was very good.

reviews.cons: Nothing I can think of
reviews.pros: I have been working as a Lead Generation Specialist at Handly.ai for over a year now and I can confidently say that this is one of the best companies I have ever worked for. The work environment is truly amazing, and I feel like I am part of a big family here. The team is very supportive and always ready to help each other out. What I love about working at Handly.ai is that we get to work with a diverse range of clients from different industries, which keeps the work interesting and challenging. As a Lead Gen Specialist, I have had the opportunity to work on some really exciting projects and have seen firsthand how our strategies and solutions have helped our clients improve their business. The leadership team at Handly.ai is truly exceptional. They are very approachable and always willing to listen to feedback and suggestions from employees. They truly value their employees and make sure that we have all the resources we need to succeed. Overall, I would highly recommend Handly.ai to anyone who is looking for a great work environment, exciting projects, and a company that truly cares about its employees. It's a great place to work, learn and grow your career.

reviews.cons: Most of the team is remote, though there are occasional meet-ups. Consulting takes strong communication and a working style that is not everyone's cup of tea.
reviews.pros: Logic is the most collaborative company I have worked for. Good, smart people working on the same team is what I love most about it. The work is interesting and usually has good growth opportunities.

reviews.advice: Respect your words and please keep the people you interview updated as promised!
reviews.cons: Nothing serious with these folks. They will waste your time with multiple interviews and no response after.
reviews.pros: Seems to be good. They pressure to interview you and advertise the company

reviews.cons: The commute to SODO gets old
reviews.pros: Love the CEO! Christian is great!

reviews.advice: It feels like our CEO is a distant observer. A suggestion could be for him to read out candidly comments from our annual employee surveys, if he sees them, to address some of our concerns and questions. When leaders yell at us in public space, it does not feel like we are putting the same amount of effort into our company values as they are. Can you please reflect on if our senior leaders are held accountable for being an example to the rest of us?
reviews.cons: A lot of employees leave after a short stay and the company has also cut a lot recently. VERY high cost per month for benefits. 1% 401k match of your yearly salary seems low for tech. Leadership loses their tempers and has yelled at co-workers in front of us. ~Every~ employee is required to make outreach to our Linkedin network to attempt to find new work for the business and asked to record your attempts for verification. Working 40 hour weeks is considered doing the minimum, so you will need to consistently bill more than 40 hours to be graded well in your reviews.
reviews.pros: Our social committee sends out fun things to do virtually. You can receive reimbursement for training opportunities, but know you may need to pay them back if you don't stay with the company long enough. There's a good effort to make consultants feel connected across remote HUBs. Clients to work with are high-profile. Smart people to work alongside with that have good industry experience to learn from. The employees that have a long tenure can start to receive more benefits.
reviews.summary: Make sure you do your due diligence on the culture

reviews.advice: CEO is absent. He needs to read survey results and digest what worker bees are saying. CEO needs to hold C Suite accountable for poor leadership. Allow fully remote and you'll include a lot more great minds. Follow the values.
reviews.cons: Leadership is poor. There are 4 C Suite people that bicker and fight amongst themselves. They and other leaders are good in practice, but bad at leading people. They shout from the rooftops at what employees should/shouldn't do and then complain whenever a task takes longer than reasonable. Attrition rate is HIGH because of one leader especially. Good people don't stick around. For a tech org, Logic20/20 operates like the 1990s. Old ways, old tech, old platform. Inefficient at best. Benefits are decent. 401k match is 1% which sucks compared to industry standards. The match is not paid until the next year and is not guaranteed if you leave. Every day is a fire drill based on what the C Suite feels priority is. Constant stress. Employees don't get acknowledged for good work or project completion. Always onto the next task. Fear based leadership = micromanaging. Careful with this. Seems innocent at first but it's not worth being apart of. They push surveys and goals to increase survey scores. Maybe look at the real problems and address them rather than force high ratings. When people leave, might or might not get severance or pto time. Subjective. Depends if leaders like them or not.
reviews.pros: The worker-bee level positions are some of the smartest and nicest people to work with. Events are engaging, fun, collaborative. Good collab for remote work. Hubs in US are growing. Good values.

reviews.advice:
Your "Culture of We" is moot with how you treat your consultants and analysts. Consultants are left holding the bag for everyone else even though we actually do the work contained within the RFPs and SoWs.

If something is a bonus, don't sic your HR dogs on me when I choose not to participate. Make it mandatory if you want it to be mandatory. Meaning, if I don't have a project to give you, then you should have a conversation with the sales team as to why they can't sell any projects, not come down on consultants because that's not our job. If your headhunter recruiters and TAs can't find anyone to work, that's their problem, not ours. Maybe they should spend less time making cute posts on LinkedIn and actually do something productive. I am working a project for you. The bonuses would be nice, and I would be happy to receive a referral bonus or the project generation bonus, but I can't just make things up out of thin air, and I am uncomfortable doing so because, and I know this is a foreign concept to most management and HR at this company, I have a moral compass and don't like to lie or cheat my way to the top. I work hard. Dang hard. And I'm smart, capable, and a quick learner. No matter how I feel or how you have treated me, you'll never take any of that away from me. That is my main job. Sales and recruitment doesn't get engaged when consultants need help on their projects, so why do sales and recruitment get catered to, and consultants are forced to do the catering? Also, why do consultants get the boot when recruitment and sales can't generate clients, employees, and projects?

I can confidently say, after being furloughed and officially severed, I don't think anyone at this company ever gave a dang (I wish Glassdoor would let me use my four-letter words. Just assume them) about me or anyone else in my situation. No one is even helping me find new work after treating the others and me so poorly. They know how bad the job market is right now, and it's frightening that they still sleep soundly at night after how they've treated some of us.

However, all of this said, this is just the culture in this god-awful country. I doubt you'll change anything, and I'm sure your HR pawn is going to come reply to this talking about all of those "accolades" given to you by companies run by other rich people and say a bunch of buzzwords to try and soften the blow. Yawn. Real people can see what working for you is like. I'm more mad at myself for trusting any of you to do the right thing. Thought I finally found a company that treats its workers with respect and would fight the good fight. Never again. Congrats Logic, I will never trust another company ever again in my life. Companies and corporations want to complain that no one is loyal anymore. Well, this kind of culture and business ethic is the cause. You know the scene in Billy Madison where they're doing the Jeopardy-esque competition, and Billy chooses Business Ethics for his opponent, and his opponent has a total meltdown because his opponent (the antagonist trying to take over Madison Hotels) has no moral compass to even have a grasp of what ethical behavior is within the context of running a business, and he's essentially just a greed-monger? That's a metaphor for the leadership, HR, and management at Logic.

I find it very strange how many new hires I've seen with Logic recently on LinkedIn when you've just furloughed/severed so many good people. "We always work hard to find projects for our consultants, but it can be difficult sometimes." as other replies have said. Riiiiight. Lots of hiring going on. The math ain't mathing! :) Keep towing that line, though, HR person.

Also, I noticed the most recent 4-star review was from a former employee that started at least 5 years ago and has subsequently moved on. Coincidentally, that review was submitted on August 7th, after your most recent mass layoff. A random ex employee coming to give a 3+ star review during a time of poor reviews isn't a good look when you're good at connecting dots, Logic. ;) Either you're creating fake reviews, or you're reaching out to old employees and begging them to offset the negative reviews because of your greedy, self-absorbed leadership/HR/management. Nice. Hey, maybe it's a coincidence. (Doubt it.)

"If you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life thinking it's stupid." Companies need to stop putting all of the load of training and upskilling on their employees and candidates. Most anyone can do anything with the right amount of guidance, training, and mentorship. Your company offers none. Your CDLs basically just say "Here's this vague area you could upskill in" and that's only if you're lucky with a CDL with some semblance of leadership and mentorship. That's not guidance. That's not training. That's acting like you're guiding people, and getting your "dopamine candy" and tricking your brain into believing you're actually doing something when you aren't, oh and fluffing your resume with a bogus title that you didn't actually do anything to earn.
reviews.cons:
Where to begin:

-As much as they claim in the replies, they don't value loyalty. They don't care how hard you work for them. You are on the chopping block at all times, and they'll make excuse after excuse about how "hard" it is to find projects for people. Interesting that a consulting firm's main barrier is... *checks notes* consulting projects. Maybe your sales team and TAs are just... bad at their jobs? If most of your replies say "It's difficult to find projects for people", then shouldn't you realize that the way your sales team goes about finding and securing projects is wrong? But that's another issue thrown onto the backs of the consultants. Essentially, if you want a project to work on, you have to generate it yourself while sales does... something? If I wanted to generate my own projects, I would be an independent consultant.

-Don't let the day 1 smiles and camaraderie fool you. Lots of crossed fingers behind backs. There will come a time where you're thrown to the wolves, no matter how hard you worked for them.

-Leadership is two-faced, and mid-management/HR tows the line, as evidenced by the other reviews gaslighting employees basically saying the "you aren't good enough, and your job is to do better to serve your corporate masters" schtick. Ironically, I would if they would just let me know what to train for them. They have no idea what they want you to do, so they can literally offer no guidance in how you can upskill, even if it's FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COMPANY.

-If you're furloughed or severed, you're hit with the classic corporate gaslight of "think of the business". I'll get right on that. I'm glad you're considering I don't know where my next mortgage payment is going to come from just because the execs want a bigger EoY bonus. My audaciousness in not "thinking of the business" is noted.

-Speaking of execs, no matter how much they want to sing the praises of the CFO, she's clearly read too many Ayn Rand books, leading to cutthroat policies when things get a little difficult. "Screw you, I got mine" is the actual culture of this company, regardless of all of their virtue signaling and empty words.

-Regardless of DEI/Volunteer policies, they WILL sever/furlough you as soon as it's inconvenient for them to keep you on payroll, no matter if you're a straight, white man or a BIPOC woman or anything in between. I worked with all types. And all types got furloughed/laid off. It's part of business, it's not necessary, but corporations act like it is. Their first and only concern is their bottom line. It's not even a publicly traded company, so they have no SEC laws holding them down with "bUt ThE sHaReHoLdErS" routines. The leadership and management could take a pay cut or a bonus reduction, any corporation could, but they'll never choose that path even though they're essentially running a dying business. "Screw you, I got mine" again. They basically make you feel secure in your job, everyone in your professional circle is totally unaware and thinks you're going to be benched, and then the day of a meeting titled "Bench Sync" they tell you you have 8 hours to decide whether you want to choose furlough or severance. The only difference is with severance, you get one extra paycheck on top of your eventual PTO payout (if you have any accrued), and with furlough, you don't get that paycheck but you keep your healthcare benefits for up to 90 days while they "try to find a project for you" and you're "top priority" for any projects that come about. So basically, you're given the choice of an extra paycheck to pay your bills for a slightly longer amount of time or rolling the dice and hoping that they find you a project. A DEI/Volunteer policy that is rendered null due to how quickly these people will throw you to the wolves when their exec bonuses are threatened.  They don't care about human beings. Therefore, they can't care about a subset of marginalized human beings. If you're given the option, just sever. They're not going to find you a project, and it's just better to hurt their wallet and hopefully try to teach them the way they're treating people is wrong.

-They give you no warning. I knew my project was coming to an end, and I made the obviously terrible choice of trusting them to put me on the bench. I should have started to look for another job, but I trusted their golden smiles. Everyone around me was totally shocked to learn I was being furloughed/severed. However, they could have given me professional courtesy and said "Hey, we don't have any spots on the bench. If we can't find you a project when this one ends, you'll probably be furloughed." And, to be clear, I wasn't the only person furloughed in this group. This is clearly a greed move. I got nothing but starry-eyed reviews from anyone involved in my circle - coworkers, CDL, and managers. It wasn't a performance-based layoff. When I pressed on this issue, their response was "Well we don't want to lose our good people." Got it. So, your idea of "not losing your best people" is basically waiting until the last second to let someone know their mortgage is insecure. Honestly, this review wouldn't be half as scathing as it is if they had just given me a fair warning. But their chosen option is to spring a furlough on you at the flip of a switch. Disgusting. Again, a self-absorbed way to handle the situation. Profits over people. Yes, HR person replying to this, I know, I know - "While we are continually looking to generate profits..." Yawn. I can't be bothered to care. Ya know. Got that whole "mortgage" thing I'm worried about. Not that that moves any of you.

-They celebrate tenured employees constantly at quarterly all-hands meetings. The problem with this is, unless you're part of the good ol' boys and girls club that came into the company from the UK/Australia with the CEO, it's pretty impossible to achieve any sort of tenure due to how easily they'll just furlough/sever people. And, at a certain point, your idea of celebrating tenure and loyalty becomes nothing more than patting yourselves on the back for furloughing people. They don't care how hard you work for them, they don't care how much effort you give, they will treat you like every other company in the US. "Profits over people. Screw the workers. Make sure leadership stays rich." They claim they invest every dollar back into the company, but if that were true, they wouldn't be furloughing and severing people at a moment's notice. Leadership would take the hit, and create more bench space with money redirected from exec salaries and bonuses. They don't. You're worthless to them. A worm on a sidewalk.

-As a consultant, you aren't just a consultant. You also have to do sales and recruitment as well. These roles are purported to be bonus ventures for consultants, but if you don't participate, you get to have a 1on1 with a snarky HR person and explain why you didn't participate and give out your friends' and family's personal information out for free. And "I don't know anyone who has the power or money to pay for a consulting project" isn't an acceptable answer. I had even referred a couple of friends already, but that didn't count. They wanted new names for their lists exactly when they demanded them. Do you all think we have gigantic social circles? Look up Dunbar's Number on Wikipedia and get back to me. I'm sure they'll turn around and gaslight me here and say, "Well, you'd be on a project if you had found one for yourself." Then what do you pay the sales people for? If I'm expected to generate my own projects, then what's the point of even having a sales department?

-They're extremely inconsiderate. You are just a pawn in their money game. An example of this is them pushing you to use up all of your PTO. At first glance, this sounds great. It sounds like the company cares about your well-being. What it really is, though, is insidiously pushing you to take vacations when you aren't prepared/don't want to so they don't have to pay out liquid cash when they inevitably find a reason to furlough/sever you.

-Most revenue comes from Microsoft projects for staff aug. Basically, if you have an 18-6 badge from Microsoft, you're at extreme risk of losing your job if they don't find you another project when your 18 months is up. And they're putting all of their eggs in one basket. So, when, I don't know, hypothetically, if they tick off your Microsoft client, they're essentially sowing seeds of discontent within Microsoft. I know of a client that has sworn off entertaining any RFPs from Logic due to terrible management of a project coming from at least three steps above me. That cookie is going to crumble, no matter how many rugby matches the CEO wants to go play with Microsoft employees. Every disgruntled Microsoft client is a sown seed of discord that will bring that eventuality to pass. It's like they have no conception of how other people operate and function. If I'm someone's friend or trusted coworker, and they tell me "Hey, I once worked with this firm and it was awful. I wouldn't advise" there's no amount of cute sales pitches from Halo Effecters that is going to make me take them up on their offer. Plenty of consulting firms around to choose from. One bad review is a death knell, and an easy way to cross someone off a list. I know I've told everyone I know that I'd never work for them again, and I'd advise them not to work for Logic either. If I did, I'd be off-project ASAP after continuing looking for other forms of employment while on-project. If they want to treat me like a disposable peon, then I'll treat them like a paycheck. Nothing more. Nothing less. Logic doesn't deserve me or the people they've screwed over. They claim they're trying to break into other markets, but I wouldn't trust anything they say as far as I can throw a 100 pound rock at this point.

-The career development is a ruse. They basically claim they help you develop your career, but it's all on paper. They give you no direction or guidance. They don't tell you what to learn or how you can better contribute, it's up to you to decide to go learn something, and if it's a skill they don't need for any potential projects in the pipeline you basically just wasted your time. If you're furloughed, there's no support to help you get back on your feet somewhere else. Not even a casual networking offer. They essentially want you to work for them or not at all even if you're not employed by them. And, let's just say they get REAL mad if your project is coming to an end and a consultant decides to jump ship instead of trusting them to do the right thing. EVERYTHING is a projection coming from the top, HR, and mid-management.

-All furloughs and bad things happening are just "flukes" and "bumps in the road" every time the question is asked in quarterly all-hands meetings. The weird part is it's becoming a pattern that they won't acknowledge. And, rest assured, they NEVER "foresee any further furloughs and layoffs coming. We really think the market is taking a turn for the better." It's always just a lie to keep you passive and lull you to sleep. If I was a betting person, I'd bet they're always looking for ways to furlough/sever people with how many times and people I've seen it happen to in the short time I was there. There's definitely a loose pattern that has been established.

- I told my CDL that I was willing to learn anything and work any project. They said that's a good thing because some people are picky about their projects. I'm not. I'm really a great employee with a penchant for learning anything new that the company wants me to, but there's no direction. They have no pipelines to advise employees to tell them what to do to help better contribute. I just want a living wage and a decent work/life balance, and that's too much for Logic to handle.

-They engage their non-compete clauses. I know that for a fact. Won't go further because I'm sure they'll come after me if I do.

-Digital Transformation consultants! - If your project is coming to an end, they will put ONE of you on a massive project, make you take the heat from the client, and essentially turn you into a meat shield so mid and upper management doesn't have to. I felt awful for the DT consultant on my project. They worked that poor person to the bone...
reviews.pros:
-Decent benefits with 401k (2% match), healthcare premiums are covered, PTO, work/life balance (for the most part). According to other reviews, wages are lower than market value. When I pressed this, I was met with an incredulous reply. I was pretty ok where I was at, but workers need to band together and get what they're owed from the rich. So, if it's low, I'll always side with my fellows in the working class as I don't tow the line or act as a lap dog like HR and mid-management does. It's low.

- Non-management employees are a delight to work with that don't just tow the line and throw you under the bus when they can get ahead by doing so. Mid-management, HR, and leadership cannot be spoken for here.

-Great place to get your foot in the door to better options. This is not a company you can spend a lot of time at as they will furlough/sever you at a moment's notice even when you bust your tail for them. (This is @ consultants only. Plenty of HR and mid-management that can "water cooler talk" and tow the line (aka bootlick) their way into staying for multiple years. Nothing you can do as a consultant other than do your job well and hope you get to stay.
reviews.summary: You are expendable, and the "culture" is a ruse. Two-faced. Expect to be laid off at a moment's notice.

reviews.cons:
- The company is still in some growing pains when it comes to standardizing some practices around employee development, but they have it in their future plans to focus on this. This can also be viewed as an opportunity to help if you are looking for additional ways to grow your career through internal initiatives. 
*if you are looking for strict structure and a clear pathway laid out for your career, Logic is not there yet. Simultaneously, know they want to hire those with an entrepreneurial spirit.
reviews.pros:
- Logic20/20 is filled with people who are great to work with (e.g., collaborative, kind, skilled)
- There are plenty of ways to get involved here to get leadership experience
- There is access to the ELT.
- The company is focused on growth now, so it's a good time to get involved.

reviews.cons: same cons as any consulting firm, there may not be projects taht exactly fit your requirements.
reviews.pros: employee friendly, good work culture

reviews.advice: Whatever actually happened was completely unprofessional, deceptive, and if you continue such practices you will gain that reputation.
reviews.cons:
After client project end, I was informed I would be placed on the bench to find a new placement. After less than a week, I was brought into a last minute meeting and informed I was being fired. For what? I had a completely positive performance review. Logic cited 'communication issues', in which the only relevant event had been a point in which I had actually ended up requesting a disability accommodation. Throughout the exit process they refused to provide any other examples of communication issues, or why they were not discussed in my performance review.

I don't know if they actually fired me over disability issues or just to keep from paying me on the bench and/or unemployment, but my recommendation to anyone and everyone is to stay far away. They will tell you they appreciate you until they yank the rug.
reviews.pros: Most of my time with Logic was spent with a client team, which was overall a positive team to be on

reviews.advice: My advice to management would be to celebrate the wins. Sales is cut throat no matter where you are but at Logic20/20 it is different. It's a very small company so everyone is in each other's business and it seems like the 'managers' are too underwater to manage anything effectively. Very poorly run company.
reviews.cons: No work/life balance, toxic culture
reviews.pros: I can't think of a single 'pro' other than being employed.
reviews.summary: Small Company, No Organization, Heavy Micromanagement

reviews.cons: No major cons - the company does have more manual processes than we'd like, but the bulk are on the roadmap to remedy.
reviews.pros:
*The Logic20/20 leadership team (at all levels) models our company values and prioritizes employee experience. There is also a significant focus on leadership development, career development, and strategic inititatives that are focused on infrastructure, including AI and automation.
*The people are phenomenal - intelligent, kind, and colloborative. 
*PTO is generous and people are encouraged to regularly schedule time off 
*Company continues to invest in healthcare benefits, 401(k) matching, and mental health benefits
*Great mix of in person and online culture events, including volunteer, learning, and social opportunities, 
*Engaged leadership team with actual open door policy (both in person and online)
*Interesting, high-impact projects at large accounts
reviews.summary: Focus on employee experience and strategic growth

reviews.cons: I don't think my perspective is so much 'biased', as it is 'experienced' in stating that growing pains are just sucky, no matter what company you work for. I've had the privilege to work at some very large companies (cough *fruit stands and shipping giants* cough), but also at the opposite end of the spectrum at startups. Either way you slice it growing pains are just that - painful. Logic seems to be experiencing that now; the change in processes, new leadership moves, adding and subtracting staff, etc. So if you're looking to that established, well-groomed, and perfectly segmented company...this probably isn't the best place for you.
reviews.pros:
From the moment I joined, I felt welcomed by my colleagues and leaders. The leadership team at Logic20/20 is not only knowledgeable and experienced, but also genuinely invested in the growth and well-being of their employees - something I will admit, not all employees here may get the opportunity to experience. I feel lucky to live in the Seattle area, where I can go into the office and see our leadership team in-person, whenever I want. It's allowed me several opportunities to casually chat with them, and you can see the genuine authenticity in "practicing what they preach" about our company values. 

There is also a strong emphasis on professional development and career autonomy here. I've benefited a lot from the learning opportunities I've had access to, but I'll be candid in stating "autonomy is not for the weak-minded." Having autonomy to learn and grow with how I see my career advancing means not always having a written path to follow from management. I have plenty of support and access to tools, sure, but it's on me to be motivated enough to use those things to advance my career. If you're a self-starter, you're going to do so SO well here.
reviews.summary: You get out of it, what you give...

Long term PM projects that aren’t very interesting. New culture or growth bs model that essentially makes consultants salesy people. They essentially made selling as part of our bonus structure.

Only 80% medical coverage and cheap with holiday allowance

glassdoor_result.summary_markdown:
# Employee Sentiments

## Reasons Employees Like Working for Logic20/20

### Positive Work Environment
- "Logic20/20 provides employees at every level of the organization with the opportunity to learn and grow in a fast-paced and professional environment." [(Consultant, Glassdoor, 2012-11-04)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW2109520.htm)
- "I've been with the firm for two years and experienced high-five worthy successes... the environment is intentionally set up to support you and help you grow." [(Senior Consultant, Glassdoor, 2015-11-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW8747606.htm)
- "The leadership team at Logic20/20 is not only knowledgeable and experienced, but also genuinely invested in the growth and well-being of their employees." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-01-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW83279866.htm)

### Great Colleagues
- "The majority of the individual contributors (field consultants) are a great bunch to work with. Super intelligent, motivated, social, helpful." [(Senior Developer, Glassdoor, 2011-12-14)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW1239301.htm)
- "Logic is the most collaborative company I have worked for. Good, smart people working on the same team is what I love most about it." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-05-26)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW76819588.htm)

### Opportunities for Growth
- "Career management is employee-driven... Logic has been great about meeting me where I am and giving me opportunities to try new things aligned with my goals." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2021-02-18)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW42704935.htm)
- "There are plenty of ways to get involved here to get leadership experience." [(Senior Consultant, Glassdoor, 2023-11-29)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW82181727.htm)

## Reasons Employees Dislike Working for Logic20/20

### Management Issues
- "Management is incompetent, disrespectful, unethical and greedy." [(Senior Developer, Glassdoor, 2011-12-14)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW1239301.htm)
- "Leadership is poor... they shout from the rooftops at what employees should/shouldn't do and then complain whenever a task takes longer than reasonable." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-08-24)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW79458998.htm)

### High Turnover and Job Insecurity
- "Unreal attrition: 100-person company and at least 10 people left in my first month." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2015-01-19)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW5732130.htm)
- "You are on the chopping block at all times, and they'll make excuse after excuse about how 'hard' it is to find projects for people." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-11-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW81851069.htm)

### Toxic Work Culture
- "Cliquey, unrealistic expectations, lack of parking in a busy area." [(Consultant, Glassdoor, 2022-12-08)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW71729382.htm)
- "The firm is a playground for white women. Exhausting." [(Project Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-05-21)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW87506863.htm)

## Key Events or Changes in the Company

### Leadership Changes
- "Leadership strives to make a great working environment and grow at the same time." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2016-12-28)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW13124449.htm)
- "The company is focused on growth now, so it's a good time to get involved." [(Senior Consultant, Glassdoor, 2023-11-29)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW82181727.htm)

### Company Culture Initiatives
- "They truly do their best to make sure the client is always happy." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2016-12-28)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW13124449.htm)
- "The company continues to invest in healthcare benefits, 401(k) matching, and mental health benefits." [(Director, Glassdoor, 2024-01-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW83277956.htm)

## Specific Details About Benefits

### Compensation and Benefits
- "Compensation was fine for the market." [(Software Developer, Glassdoor, 2014-07-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW4637543.htm)
- "PTO is generous and people are encouraged to regularly schedule time off." [(Director, Glassdoor, 2024-01-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW83277956.htm)

### 401(k) and Health Benefits
- "1% 401k match is deplorable." [(Consultant, Glassdoor, 2022-11-03)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW70754764.htm)
- "Healthcare premiums are covered, PTO, work/life balance (for the most part)." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-11-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW81851069.htm)

### Training and Development
- "Some resources are lacking in terms of standardized training or learning opportunities." [(Consultant, Glassdoor, 2012-11-04)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Logic20-20-RVW2109520.htm)
